Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2008 05:02PM golfgirl wrote: I had bi-lat with expanders too. My Surgery was at 5:30pm on a Wednesday. I left the hospital about 2pm the next day.  It's really do-able as long as no issues arise.
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy as 23-hour outpatient econmom Scrappygrl

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2008 03:19PM golfgirl wrote: I saw my Onc today and finally got my date to start chemo - Tues Oct 14th.  My PET/CT and bone scans were clear.  MUGA was 77%.  Will start with AC every other week  4x.  Also Neulasta shot the day after each treatment.  Onc gave me prescriptions for 4 different anti-nausea drugs (3 to take preventatively and 1 as needed for actual occurance).  I'll head out tomorrow with the shopping list I've put together from everything I've seen posted.  I'm not looking forward to this but I know I can do it.  Thanks to everyone who has posted such valuable info.  Bless us all.
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2008 08:55PM golfgirl wrote: I'm 53 and had bi-lat with expanders on sep 10th.  I'll be starting chemo 2nd week of Oct (AC then T+Herceptin then herceptin for remainder of 1 yr).   I suspect the anxiousness of waiting is probably worse than the actual experience -  at least that's what I'm hoping for.   I have PET and Bone scans and MUGA tests scheduled over the next 10 days.  These darn expanders feel like someone sewed pointy pieces of hard plastic in there.  Someone said that they'd feel better once I start to get them filled -  I certainly hope so.  Mostly I'm sleep deprived since I can't get comfortable in any position except on my back.  I'm going to try an Ambien CR tonight.  I'm so grateful I discovered this web site.  The info has been sooo useful.  I can't wait for the day when I can get back on the golf course.    <<smile>>
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 11:20PM golfgirl wrote: I was in for1 night.  Surgery was not until 5:30pm on Wed Sept 10th.  Only thing I recall from that evening was talking to DH and sister in my room about 9-ish.  Had morphine pump and used it a couple times during the night but mostly to help get me back to sleep each time they woke me up to do a check of vitals.  Pain wasn't too bad, I just felt really sore.   Next morning I was nauseous a bit .  I finally realized that the nausea was because I hadn't had anything to eat since midnight the day before surgery and there was nothing in my stomach but acid.  I ate Saltines and felt so much better.   I got up and walked around a bit.  Ate soup for lunch and left the hospital at around 3pm on Thursday.   I believe that it's best to get out of the hospital as soon as possible.  No matter how hard they try, hospitals are where the germs and sepsis are.
Posts.Title: How Long in Hospital after Bi-Later with Reconstruction? Mocity mom_of_2

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2008 11:44AM golfgirl wrote: Mustanggirl,  Welcome to you.   I also have  a lymph node that showed up on each mammogram of my right breast.  The written report always contained a note mentioning that the lymph node was there.   Lymph nodes are are amazingly variable in their locations.  Hopefully you will have a benign result on the tumor mentioned in the report.  It's fantastic that you've found this forum so early in your process.  I've found it to be a great source of help and hope.   My bi-lat surgery is next week and I've learned so much from everyone out there.  I know I'm better prepared.  Knowledge is Power.     Best to you,   Golfgirl
Posts.Title: lymph nodes & mammogram mustanggirl ginger2345

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2008 05:06PM golfgirl wrote: I'm scheduled for bi-lat, SNB (on left), and immed expanders reconstruction on Sept10th.  In some ways it seems too soon (to get everything done I want to do before hand), but in some ways it's just another Hurry Up and Wait event that I'd just as soon get behind me.  I'm still waiting for HER2 (FISH) results and for BRCA results.  My left breast has the most amazing colors of bruising from the core biopsy.  I'm 53 and never thought much about my breasts, but this has made me realize that I really did like them and will miss them.  My hubby is surely going to miss their "reactions".   About twice a week I have a pity party for myself  (usually while in the shower).  My mom had bc at age 65 and she's 81 and a very healthy now, so she's my role model.  This whole thing is the pits, but you just do what you have to do and keep moving on with life.  Best of luck to all of us.
